explanation: Agent A is correct. In the declaration char *const *const argv, argv[i] has type char *const — a (const) pointer to a non-const char. The function only reads the strings (calls strcmp and prints them) and does not modify the characters pointed to, so the pointed-to type could and should be const-qualified (e.g. const char *const *const argv) to reflect that the data are not modified. That is exactly what MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 mandates: pointers should point to const-qualified types whenever possible. (Note: changing the parameter type may require adjusting call sites or the prototype of main; if that is infeasible because of external API constraints this should be documented/justified.)
